p: While running a game, you, the Game Master, are expected to run your combat encounters smoothly and efficiently. We know that sometimes encounters are straight-forward and easy to monitor, but what if they become more complicated? How do you keep track of Orc number 12's hit points? How can you know exactly when a character will bleed out? How do you keep track of a character's new initiative order when they delay their action? How can you keep readied actions straight? Is there a way to do secret skill checks and saves for all your characters at once? Or an easier way to mix up the action by rolling initiative at the top of every round?

If you have ever wondered if there was a better way to manage your encounters, then Turn Watcher™ is the solution for you! Turn Watcher tracks any number of player characters' (PCs) and opponents' initiative order and hit points, freeing you to run your encounters smoothly and efficiently.
Turn Watcher can:

ul.li: Roll individual initiative die rolls for every PC and opponent and put them into initiative order automatically--all with a single click!
Allow for changes in initiative, such as delayed or readied actions, or even extra opponents that enter into combat
Easily monitor the number of rounds in a combat
List PC and opponent current hit points, and automatically bleed out dying PCs and opponents, and marking them as dead at -10hp
Make secret skill checks and saves for all characters at once
Allow all actions to be done/redone

p: It's easy to make Turn Watcher a valuable tool in your GM arsenal. The basics are:

ol.li: Create a character list of each PC involved in combat (you can reuse this list over and over for each encounter)
Import the PC and opponent lists for your encounter

tr.td: The very first time you start Turn Watcher, you will be presented with a blank slate.

p: The very first thing to do is to input the relevant information from each player character (PC) in your campaign (we recommend doing this before game). You only need to enter this information once, since Turn Watcher will remember it all for you. You can also update this information as characters level.

tr.td: To begin your character list, click on the Add button on the toolbar. The Add Character dialog will appear. Enter the character name, initiative modifier, spot and listen modifiers, and the will save modifier. Then enter the character's maximum hit points. Lastly, choose "Character" from the pull down list.

p.i: Tip: Hit the <TAB> key to advance to the next field.

p: Continue these steps until you've entered all the information for all your characters. Then click "OK".

tr.td: Example: Doug enters the stats for Shiena, a human barbarian. He clicks the "Add" button and types "Shiena" in the Character Name field. He then advances to the next field by hitting the <TAB> key and enters Shiena's Initiative modifier, her Spot and Listen modifiers, her Will save, and finally her maximum hit points in the Max Hit Points field. He leaves Current Damage at 0, and then makes sure the Character Type is set for "Character". He then clicks "OK".

p: Once you've entered all of the PCs that will be participating in the campaign, you can Export your character list. Choose File|Export. Type a filename and click the Save button.

tr.td: Example: Doug is running a campaign for four players He enters each PC's relevant stats and Exports to a file called "Doug's Campaign".

p: Clear out any existing PCs and opponents by clicking File|Clear. Make sure you exported any PCs that you added in the previous step.

tr.td: Adding opponents to your encounter is similar to adding PCs, but you choose "Monster" instead of "Character" at the bottom pull-down menu in the Add Character dialog.

p: For each encounter, add the opponents or opponents that will combat the PCs. Export the newly added opponents to a filename appropriate for your encounter.

p.i: Tip: For quick duplication of opponents, highlight the opponent you wish to duplicate and select Duplicate from the Edit pulldown menu. Turn Watcher will ask how many times you want to duplicate the selected character or opponent. You can even do this during combat!

tr.td: Example: Doug is planning an encounter where the party will run into four ghouls. He clicks the Add button and types in "Ghoul 1" in the Character Name field and enters the ghoul's Initiative, Spot, Listen, and Will save modifiers, and its Max Hit Points. He ensures the Character Type is set for "Monster". He then clicks "OK" to store the new opponent. He then highlights "Ghoul 1" and selects "Duplicate" from the "Edit" pulldown menu. When the Duplicate window pops up, he enters the number 3 and clicks "OK". He now has four ghouls to engage his players.

h3: Exporting a List of Opponents for an Encounter
p: Now that you have entered the opponents that you want the PC party to face in the encounter, Export your opponent list. Choose File|Export and type a filename , then click the Save button.
Example: Doug chooses File|Export and Exports his list of 4 Ghouls as a file called "Ghoul Encounter". He then clicks File|Clear, then begins another list of opponents for the next encounter.
Repeat the above steps for each encounter you are have planned for your game. Hint: Create a few random encounter lists that you can use in any game in your campaign.
Now you are ready to actually start using Turn Watcher in your game!

ul.li: Start the application and clear out the list of characters if needed.
Import (File|Import) your list of characters for your campaign.

td.li: Next, Import (File|Import) your list of opponents for this encounter. Turn Watcher will ask you if you want to merge with your existing characters. Click the Yes button.

Start your combat by clicking the "Start" button (once it has been clicked, the "Start" button will change to an "End" button). Turn Watcher automatically rolls separate initiative rolls for every PC and monster and lists them in initiative order for you! It also keeps track of rounds in the status bar at the bottom of the main window.

ul.li: Press the "Next" button to move from one character to the next after it takes its full action. The character's turn is marked with an arrow (shaped like a sword) to the left of the name. Tip: Hit the <SPACE> key to easily advance to the next character.

td.li: To come out of rounds, click the "End" button.

p: Hint: If at any time you make a mistake and want to undo your action, simply select Edit|Undo.

tr.td: When a PC or monster takes damage in combat, highlight the appropriate character and click on the Damage button. Enter the amount of damage and press the Add Damage button. Note that this does not change the initiative order as the arrow does not change.

p: If a character receives healing, repeat the same steps but enter the amount of healing and press the Add Health button. A character can also be brought up to its full health automatically by clicking Bring to Full.

p.i: Tip: You may also apply mass damage or healing by highlighting those characters you wish to effect and clicking on the Damage button.

tr.td: If a character is Dying (i.e. the hit points have fallen below zero (0) but has not yet reached negative ten (-10), Turn Watcher will automatically bleed the character out one (1) hit point at the end of each of the creature's turn (until he is Stabilized--see below).

If a Dying character becomes stabilized, then click Rounds|Stabilize and the status will change from "Dying" to "Stabilized". Turn Watcher will no longer bleed the character out after his turn unless he sustains more damage or is healed back to zero (0) or more hit points.

If a character reaches negative ten (-10) hit points, then Turn Watcher automatically marks the character "Dead" and greys out the character, automatically skipping her in initiative. You can also purge dead characters and monsters by highlighting and clicking the Delete button.

p.i: Tip: You can disable the skip feature by clicking on Rounds|Skip Dead Characters.

tr.td: If a character chooses to delay his action, click on the Delay button on the toolbar; the character status changes to "Delayed". Once the character is ready to jump in, click on the "Jump In" button. If more than one combat participant is delayed, Turn Watcher will ask you which one is jumping in.

p: If a character chooses to ready an action, click on the "Ready" button on the toolbar; the character status changes to "Readied". Once the PC or monster action is triggered, click on the "Jump In" button. If more than one combat participant has a readied action, Turn Watcher will ask you which one is jumping in.
Turn Watcher automatically expires readied actions and delays when a character or opponent's turn comes up in the next round.
h2: Making Secret Skill Checks and Will Saves

tr.td: Use Turn Watcher to quickly and secretly make separate die rolls for each character by clicking on one of the colored dice icons on the toolbar. You can even sort the players/monsters by clicking on the appropriate column.

p: Example: The party moves into a new chamber in the dungeon. Doug wants to secretly roll the players' spot check to see if they notice a hidden door in a room. He clicks the "Spot" button on the toolbar, then clicks the "Spot" column to sort. The characters with the highest "Spot" checks are listed first.
h2: Changing One or More Characters' Initative Order
p: With Turn watcher you can add or import characters during active combat. The new characters are placed at the end of the initative order. You may move one or more characters up or down in initiative order by first highlighting the target characters and clicking Rounds|Move Up or Rounds|Move Down.

p.i: Tip: Use the <CONTROL> Up Arrow to move characters up in initiative order. Similarly, <CONTROL> Down Arrow moves characters down in initiative order.

tr.td: If you're one of those GMs that likes to mix up the action, select Ultra Initiative via the "Rounds" menu. Ultra Initiative mode causes Turn Watcher to automatically re-roll initiative at the top of each round.

p.i: Tip: Use Ctrl-U to turn on or off Ultra Initiative at any time while in or out of rounds!

p: You can use shortcut keys to access Turn Watcher's many features, instead of via the menus and toolbar.
